一名在摩洛哥地震中失去双亲的男子表示，挖掘机械花了四天时间才到达偏远小镇，他的父母被埋在倒塌的四层住宅下，他觉得政府的反应背叛了他。

当军用直升机飞过高阿特拉斯山脉的塔拉特·恩亚库布上空时，贾迈勒·拉巴基希望他们还活着，与他的兄弟、叔叔和邻居一起，徒手在废墟中拼命搜寻。

“我们等待帮助，”他在现场告诉路透社。 “人们死在废墟下，但没有人帮忙。”

拉巴基说，他不明白为什么政府的救援花了这么长时间才到达该镇，也不明白为什么在震区有这么多人遭受苦难时，一些外国援助的提议尚未被接受。

他说：“这是背叛。彻头彻尾的背叛。”他补充说，在某些地区，人们仍然被困在破烂的建筑物下。

据国家电视台报道，周五晚上袭击高阿特拉斯山脉的 6.8 级地震造成的死亡人数周二上升至 2,901 人，受伤人数增加了一倍多，达到 5,530 人。受灾山区的村民经常对没有得到国家的帮助表示沮丧。

摩洛哥军方正在带头开展救援工作，军队人员和紧急救援人员已在塔拉特·尼亚库布驻扎数天。

军方表示正在加强搜救队伍，提供饮用水并分发食物、帐篷和毯子，而政府则表示正在实地尽一切努力。

但地震灾区幅员辽阔、崎岖不平、地处偏僻。一些道路因山体滑坡而被封锁，一些受灾最严重的地区只能通过直升机到达。

附近村庄的居民也讲述了与拉巴基类似的故事。他们独自寻找亲人，在没有任何政府援助的情况下救出了幸存者并埋葬了死者。

周边村庄的许多人表示，他们靠当地慈善机构的捐款生存，从中央国家当局得到的帮助很少或根本没有。

“那些应该帮助人民的人并不关心，”拉巴基说。

他说，塔拉特·尼亚库布的大多数人都感觉当局在拒绝他们。 “这立刻就像一把刀插在你的心上。我们爱摩洛哥。这是我们的国家。这是我们的土壤。”

地震发生时，拉巴基正在马拉喀什，这座历史名城距离震中 72 公里（45 英里）。他花了12个小时才从那里行驶了约100公里到达Talat N'Yaaqoub。

他说，在等待连接他的家乡和马拉喀什的被封锁的Tizi n'Test公路上的残骸被清理干净时，他绝望地多次尝试通过电话联系他的父母，但没有得到答复。

亚历山大·康威尔报道；马克·海因里希和亚历克斯·理查森编辑; Tue, 12 Sep 2023 19:10:32 GMT https://www.reuters.com/world/africa/this-is-betrayal-moroccan-who-lost-parents-earthquake-angry-over-government-2023-09-12/ https://www.reuters.com/world/africa/this-is-betrayal-moroccan-who-lost-parents-earthquake-angry-over-government-2023-09-12/Alexander Cornwell摩洛哥地震/悲剧 (PIX) Pulitzer winner Chabon, other authors sue Meta over AI program

周二，包括普利策奖得主 Michael Chabon 在内的一群作家在旧金山联邦法院起诉 Meta Platforms (META.O) ，指控这家科技巨头滥用他们的作品来训练其 Llama 人工智能软件。

Chabon、托尼奖得主剧作家 David Henry Hwang 以及作家 Matthew Klam、Rachel Louise Snyder 和 Ayelet Waldman 在诉讼中表示， Meta 教会 Llama 大语言模型使用包含盗版作品的数据集来响应人类文本提示。

周五，这些作者对 ChatGPT 制造商 OpenAI 提起了类似的集体诉讼。作者表示，在 OpenAI 案例中，书籍和戏剧等作品对于人工智能语言训练特别有价值，因为它们是“高质量长篇写作的最佳范例”。

Meta 的发言人拒绝就新诉讼发表评论。作者的律师没有立即回应置评请求。

7 月份，Meta 和 OpenAI 还因侵犯版权而被另一组作者起诉，其中包括喜剧演员莎拉·西尔弗曼 (Sarah Silverman)，这是针对人工智能公司的版权案件不断增加的一部分。

Meta 发布了用于训练第一版 Llama 模型的数据集列表，该模型于 2 月份发布。该公司没有透露其最新版本 Llama 2 的训练数据。

Llama 2 是 Meta 公开用于商业用途的第一个大型语言模型，每月活跃用户数低于 7 亿的公司可以免费使用。

Llama 2 的发布被视为新兴生成人工智能软件市场的潜在游戏规则改变者，有可能颠覆 OpenAI 和谷歌等使用其模型收取高额费用的参与者的早期主导地位。

路透社/益普索的一项民意调查显示，美国总统乔·拜登的公众支持率本月小幅升至自 3 月份以来的最高水平，尽管众议院共和党人启动了正式的弹劾调查，但在民主党成员的支持下，拜登的公众支持率仍小幅上升至 3 月份以来的最高水平。

这项为期三天的民意调查于周日结束，显示拜登的支持率较上个月略有上升，当时有 40% 的受访者表示认可他自 2021 年 1 月上任以来的表现。

该民意调查的误差幅度为三个百分点，显示拜登的支持率很大程度上取决于党派之争。大约 80% 的自称是民主党人的人支持拜登，比 8 月份略有上升。

百分之九十一的共和党人不赞成拜登。

自2021年8月以来，拜登的公众支持率一直保持在50%以下。

美国众议院议长、共和党人凯文·麦卡锡周二呼吁对拜登进行弹劾调查，这加大了 2024 年总统选举前党派斗争的风险。

共和党人指责拜登在2009年至2017年担任副总统期间从其儿子亨特·拜登的海外商业企业中获利，尽管他们没有提供实质性证据。白宫表示没有调查依据。

在拜登之前的四位美国总统中，两位——比尔·克林顿和唐纳德·特朗普——被美国众议院弹劾，并被美国参议院宣告无罪。

在共和党支持对民主党人克林顿进行弹劾调查后，共和党在 1998 年中期选举中失去了众议院席位。在对特朗普进行两次民主党支持的调查后，这位共和党总统在 2020 年连任竞选中输给了拜登。

路透社/益普索的最新民意调查显示，经济仍然是美国人最关心的问题，23%的受访者将其视为“当今美国面临的最重要问题”。

拜登任期内，美国通胀率一直处于历史高位，促使央行行长提高利率以抑制物价上涨。

约13%的受访者选择“犯罪或腐败”作为首要问题。

路透社/益普索 (Reuters/Ipsos) 民意调查使用具有全国代表性的样本，在线收集了 1,029 名成年人的回答。

巴拿马运河管理人员周二表示，如果今年的干旱持续下去，巴拿马运河可能会进一步减少每天授权的最大船只过境数量。

今年早些时候，该运河开始限制船只吃水，并授权每日通行以节约用水，这导致等待通过这条全球主要跨洋通道的船只积压，该通道处理着约占世界贸易量的 5%。

这些措施迫使许多船只在通过前减载货物，并导致圣诞节即将到来之前的运费上涨。

目前每天有多达 32 艘船舶获准过境，而正常情况下为 36 艘。今年早些时候，船舶吃水深度也从 50 英尺限制为最大 44 英尺。

为了缓解船舶等待的瓶颈，运河最近改变了预订系统，允许更多未预订的船舶通过，并优先考虑等待时间最长的船舶。

官方数据显示，截至周二，共有 116 艘船只在巴拿马等待通过，而 8 月初这一数字为 160 多艘。 Vasquez 表示，最长等待时间也从一个月前的 21 天减少到 14 天。

巴拿马运河管理局局长里考尔特·巴斯克斯表示，如果需要，该航道将选择减少每日过境量，然后再计划进一步削减授权船舶吃水，这对托运人影响最大。

“今年的厄尔尼诺现象非常严重。太平洋和大西洋同时出现高温，”瓦斯克斯在新闻发布会上告诉记者。 “我们预计，在接下来的几个月里，如果没有大雨，我们必须做好准备。”

长期干旱

瓦斯克斯表示，尽管这次干旱并不是巴拿马有史以来最严重的一次，但它可能会持续很长时间。

上周，为该水道供水的加通湖水位为 24.2 米（79.7 英尺），而近年来 9 月份的水位为 26.6 米。

瓦斯克斯补充说，如果干旱持续超过 12 个月，运河可能会被迫改变其天气模型，这可能会引发额外的限制。

“我们不认为运河会暂停运营，”他说。

从长远来看，巴拿马需要改变流向加通湖的水流方式，以确保运河有足够的水源，每艘通过运河的船只使用 5000 万加仑（1.9 亿升）淡水。

瓦斯奎兹说：“我们正在热切地与当局合作，以便做出安排，建造更多的水库。”他补充说，该提案需要修改立法，必须提交给国会。

专家警告称，在明年更加干旱的时期之前，海上贸易可能会受到干扰。他们认为，巴拿马旱季可能提前开始，气温高于平均水平，可能会增加蒸发量，导致四月份水位接近创纪录的低水位。

奥地利反腐败检察官周二表示，由于缺乏证据，他们已放弃对前保守派财政部长格诺特·布鲁梅尔的贿赂调查。

此次调查是针对所谓的伊维萨刺杀视频中潜在腐败的众多调查之一，在该视频中，极右翼自由党时任领导人海因茨·克里斯蒂安·斯特拉赫 (Heinz-Christian Strache) 被秘密拍摄，指控奥地利腐败，后来他对这些指控进行了调查。他说他不是那个意思。

其中许多调查仍在继续。

2019年这段视频的出现促使斯特拉赫辞去奥地利副总理职务，并导致该党与保守派的执政联盟崩溃，当时由布鲁梅尔的亲密盟友塞巴斯蒂安·库尔茨领导。

布鲁梅尔否认了这些指控，对他的调查重点是 2017 年他与一家赌博公司经理之间的短信交流，该经理在短信中要求与时任外交部长库尔兹会面，讨论该国的税务问题。一个外国，并提到可能向其政党捐款。

“在本案中，要构成犯罪，需要有捐赠或具体提供与犯罪相关的优势，以换取官员的行动。无法证明赌博公司向该党提供的具体捐赠， ”中央经济犯罪和腐败检察官办公室（WKStA）在一份声明中表示。

报告补充称，也无法充分确定 Bluemel 是否转达了该请求、提及捐赠或在该公司与部长之间的任何会议上提出了潜在的犯罪要约。

2019年政府垮台后，库尔兹带领保守派在议会选举中获胜，但因腐败指控接受调查而被迫于2021年辞去总理职务。他还因在向议会委员会作证时可能作伪证而接受调查。他否认有任何不当行为。

布鲁梅尔和库尔兹都退出了政坛。他们的政党继续留在政府，并领导与绿党于 2020 年组成的联盟。

当地官员周二表示，意大利兰佩杜萨岛正面临创纪录数量的船只移民登陆问题，并称情况“非常严重”。

兰佩杜萨是意大利最南端，也是来自北非的人们的第一个停靠港，长期以来一直是欧洲移民危机的爆发点。

当地警察局长埃马努埃莱·里西法里 (Emanuele Ricifari) 告诉路透社，每天抵达该岛的移民船只数量已超过上个月创下的 63 艘的记录，预计到当天结束时将达到 80 艘左右。

他说，岛上的“热点”接待中心约有 2,800 名移民（官方容量仅为 400 人左右），岛上其他地区也有约 300 人。

这些移民都将被转移到更大的西西里岛，以缓解过度拥挤并为未来抵达的人腾出空间。

ANSA 和 AGI 通讯社援引省政府官员菲利波·罗马诺 (Filippo Romano) 的话说：“情况确实非常严重。”

市长菲利波·曼尼诺 (Filippo Mannino) 告诉 Adnkronos 通讯社：“今天我们可能会实现 100 次登陆，但该岛已经无法再维持这些数字了。”

根据内政部数据，自今年年初以来，总体而言已有约 118,500 名乘船移民抵达意大利，几乎是 2022 年同期记录的 64,529 人的两倍。

去年当选的总理乔治亚·梅洛尼（Giorgia Meloni）承诺打击非正常移民，但突尼斯对移民的镇压和利比亚持续的混乱导致来自北非的越海移民数量增加，但未能降低移民数量。

西班牙南部安达卢西亚地区政府计划购买多纳纳国家公园周围的大片土地，以保护和扩大受到频繁干旱、气温上升和非法用水威胁的湿地。

地区领导人胡安马·莫雷诺周二表示，计划购买 7,500 公顷（18,533 英亩）的土地将使多纳纳的面积扩大 14%，他称之为“过去几十年来保护公园的最大行动”。

科学家警告说，该公园受到气候变化和非法灌溉的威胁，泻湖干涸，生物多样性消失，状况危急，并敦促减少抽水。

多纳纳湿地栖息着许多特有和受威胁的物种，如淡水鳗鱼和海龟，为在北欧繁殖后南下的候鸟提供了重要的避难所。

过去 12 个月，西班牙的平均降雨量比 1991 年至 2020 年期间的平均降雨量低 17%。环境部表示，气候变化导致干旱日益频繁和严重，西班牙比其他欧洲国家更容易受到影响。

在计划购买土地之前，莫雷诺的保守派政府因其计划将多纳纳周围的额外灌溉合法化而受到环保主义者和马德里政府的严厉批评。

此次收购包括 Veta la Palma 庄园约 3,500 公顷的人工湿地，该湿地在 2021 年之前一直用作养鱼场，现在面临干涸的风险。

多纳纳的泻湖周围是一片温室和复杂的管道系统，这些管道系统从非法钻井中取水，供种植草莓和其他浆果的农民使用。

代理环境部长特蕾莎·里贝拉（Teresa Ribera）领导的社会党领导的国家政府发誓要保护该公园，她对这项措施表示欢迎，但表示这并不能解决缺水问题。

麦卡锡对记者说：“我正在指示我们的众议院委员会对乔·拜登总统展开正式弹劾调查。”

当当时由民主党控制的众议院在 2019 年和 2021 年两次弹劾共和党总统唐纳德·特朗普时，麦卡锡党内的许多人感到愤怒，尽管他两次在参议院都被宣告无罪。

在2020年大选中击败特朗普的拜登正在寻求明年连任。目前以微弱优势控制众议院的共和党人指责拜登在 2009 年至 2017 年担任副总统期间从其儿子亨特·拜登的外国商业企业中获利，尽管他们尚未提供证据。

根据上个月发布的一份文字记录，小拜登的一位前商业伙伴在众议院听证会上表示，亨特·拜登在他父亲担任副总统期间出售了获得权力的“ 幻想”。

白宫表示没有调查依据，拜登还就可能的弹劾嘲笑共和党人。

民主党人试图将共和党的弹劾言论描述为转移公众对特朗普法律困境的注意力的努力，特朗普在竞选党内提名以在 2024 年美国大选中与拜登对决时面临四项单独的刑事起诉。

特朗普敦促共和党人试图将拜登赶下台。几位极右翼共和党人表示，除非麦卡锡批准弹劾调查，否则他们不会投票支持必须通过的支出法案。

美国宪法授权国会以叛国、贿赂和“其他重罪和轻罪”为由弹劾包括总统在内的联邦官员。如果众议院以简单多数批准弹劾条款，并且参议院在审判后以三分之二多数投票定罪，则总统可以被免职。

任何弹劾拜登的努力都不太可能成功。即使共和党控制的众议院投票弹劾拜登——考虑到该党以 222 票对 212 票的微弱优势，弹劾拜登的前景不确定——也几乎肯定会在民主党控制的参议院失败。

特朗普是唯一一位两次被弹劾的美国总统。由于共和党同僚的投票阻止了参议院获得定罪所需的三分之二多数票，他在参议院审判后两次被无罪释放。

  • G20 summit seen boosting Modi's standing ahead of elections
  • Modi's BJP planning to cash in on his enhanced image
  • Rising inflation, unemployment will be countered, analysts say
  • Opposition says Modi turned G20 into 'election campaign'

The weekend G20 summit was India's big moment on the world stage, giving the country an opportunity to work on global issues and providing Prime Minister Narendra Modi a chance to present his credentials as a global statesman.

Although some analysts said the meeting showed few concrete results , his Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) is now cashing in on Modi's enhanced image ahead of a series of state elections and national elections due by May 2024.

In the run-up to the summit, Modi's face was plastered on G20 hoardings across the country. During the meeting last weekend, local television channels had wall-to-wall coverage of Modi with world leaders, including US President Joe Biden, and the praise that was showered on him for a successful meeting.

The BJP peppered its social media platforms with messages of praise from world leaders.

The summit declaration papered over key differences and had few breakthroughs in critical areas such as debt and climate change but for a popular leader with a long-dominant lead over his political rivals, these are diplomatic intricacies that matter little in domestic politics, analysts said.

India's successful mission last month to land a spacecraft on the moon is another factor that feeds into the country's feel-good image and gives Modi a fillip, they said.

The opposition Congress party has criticised Modi for turning G20 into an election campaign, charging him with promoting dialogue and peace on the international stage while his Hindu nationalist administration discriminates against religious minorities and quashes dissent, charges the government has denied.

But analysts say Modi's political position is so strong there is little risk of the strategy backfiring.

"The message which has gone out is that India has really emerged very strong in the world," said Sanjay Kumar, psephologist at New Delhi's Centre for the Study of Developing Societies.

"And it's only because of Modi. The narrative is the national pride of an average Indian has gone up," he said.

Modi enjoys high approval ratings and surveys suggest he will easily win the general election and a third term next year despite concerns about rising inflation, unemployment and an uneven economic recovery after the COVID-19 pandemic. Worries about violence in the northeastern state of Manipur have also affected Modi's image.

The BJP plans to highlight the "success of the summit" during fortnight-long celebrations of Modi's birthday starting on Sunday, a party official said.

Modi's contribution to India's rising global stature will be a key theme of a special five-day parliament session beginning next week, the official said.

NATIONAL PRIDE

"It's really a fact that India's image has transformed under Prime Minister Modi," BJP vice president Baijayant Jay Panda told Reuters.

Modi, who turns 73 on Sunday, swept to power in 2014 promising stability and change from what he called the long-ruling Congress party's corruption and poor governance.

He consolidated his win with welfare economics, boosting infrastructure and unabashed Hindu nationalism, winning a second term in 2019 with a bigger majority.

Modi often underlines national pride in his speeches, which resonates with a large section of the people that has been aggrieved about India's portrayal in Western media as a poor country, analysts said.

"Every small thing counts when a narrative of national pride is being built," said Yashwant Deshmukh, a psephologist with the C-Voter agency.

According to C-Voter's biannual "Mood of the Nation" survey in India Today magazine last month, 47% said India's G20 presidency will enhance the country's global stature and 73% said it will be a poll plank in 2024.

The opposition Congress party was not so impressed, with its chief spokesperson Jairam Ramesh saying Modi's statements of tolerance on the global stage are "sheer hypocrisy".

"At home...he remains silent on hate speech, lynchings, targeted killings, and attacks on holy places. His party, and the larger ecosystem he belongs to, has unleashed systematic polarisation campaigns...and has torn apart the social fabric of the nation," Ramesh posted on X, formerly Twitter.

The government has denied these charges.

Former Congress prime minister Manmohan Singh, who Modi replaced, said: "While India's standing in the world should rightfully be an issue in domestic politics, it is equally important to exercise restraint in using diplomacy and foreign policy for party or personal politics."

The son of Aung San Suu Kyi, Myanmar's detained former leader, said he was "extremely worried" about his mother's health, saying she was struggling to eat and was being refused permission to see an outside doctor.

The 78-year-old Nobel laureate, who has been detained for more than two years, has experienced bouts of dizziness and vomiting, and is suffering from a serious gum disease, her son, Kim Aris, who lives in Britain, told Reuters.

"I am extremely worried about the state she is in," he said. "She is not as robust as she once was. If she is unable to eat, then things are not looking very hopeful."

Myanmar has been in turmoil since early 2021, when the military overthrew Suu Kyi's elected government and cracked down on opponents of military rule, with thousands jailed or killed.

Suu Kyi is facing 27 years of detention related to 14 criminal offences. She denies all the charges for which she was convicted, ranging from incitement and election fraud to corruption, and has been appealing against them.

The Myanmar embassy in London did not respond to a request for comment about Suu Kyi's health and conditions. A spokesperson for the military government did not answer calls on Tuesday and the junta's information team did not immediately respond to a request for comment.

Aris, 45, who in 1991 as a teenager collected the Nobel peace prize for his mother who was under house arrest at the time, has had no contact with his mother since she was most recently detained and the military have not responded to his repeated requests.

"There is no way of communicating with her," he said. "She is not even allowed care packages. She is not allowed access to her legal counsel. She is not allowed visitors. She is not allowed to mingle with other prisoners. It is basically a form of solitary confinement."

In August the military pardoned Suu Kyi on five of the 19 offences for which she was convicted but said she would remain under house arrest. State media reported she had been moved from jail to house arrest shortly before.

Aris said it was untrue that she had been moved.

"They are trying to disseminate this disinformation about my mother being moved to house arrest. This is all about appeasing the international community, but the international community is well aware of this disinformation."

Many governments have called for the unconditional release of Suu Kyi and thousands of other political prisoners, and some, including the United States, European Union and Britain, have targeted the Southeast Asian country's military with sanctions.

Aris has spoken with Britain's foreign ministry, but he said there was little the government could do because they did not have a working relationship with the military.

The international community needed to continue putting pressure on the military, including tougher sanctions, he said.

Aris said he mainly relies on information from Myanmar television channels and social media to keep updated.

Asked if he is concerned that he may never see his mother again, he said: "Obviously, it is a worry."

消息人士称，去年日本媒体报道该计划后，这一举措被叫停，凸显了东京对北京反应的紧张。

日本防卫省表示，它只会与台湾（1895年至1945年期间是日本殖民地）建立“非政府”关系，这种关系在1972年联合声明的范围内，该声明承认北京是中国的唯一合法政府。

当被问及新任武官时，台湾外交部拒绝置评，但表示“将继续深化与日本等志同道合的伙伴的合作”。

忧虑

北京在距离日本领土仅 100 公里（62 英里）的岛屿周围扩大军事存在，令东京感到不安。它担心卷入任何冲突，这些冲突也可能威胁到向日本供应大部分石油的附近海上航线。

周一，台湾表示，由山东号航空母舰率领的中国海军编队在前往西太平洋的途中经过了距离台湾海岸60海里的地方。

对此类演习的担忧促使人们呼吁日本与台湾建立安全联系，包括直接的军事接触，这可能有助于日本制定应急计划。

然而，北京可能将任何关系升级视为干涉其内政。

去年8月，中国以军事演习回应时任美国众议院议长南希·佩洛西访问台湾，其中包括在日本岛屿附近海域进行导弹袭击。

四个月后，日本首相岸田文雄政府公布了日本自第二次世界大战以来最大规模的军备建设，国防开支在五年内翻了一番，用于支付远程打击导弹、先进战斗机的开发以及弹药库存的费用。以及在持续冲突中所需的备件。

在随附的国家安全评估中，中国政府表示，台湾海峡的和平对于国际稳定至关重要。

中国批评日本、美国和其他西方国家采取所谓的冷战思维。

到目前为止，还没有日本政府高级官员访问过台湾，但近几个月来，几名议员前往台湾，扩大了非官方旅行范围，以表达对台湾的支持。

议员外交包括前首相、执政党自民党副总裁麻生太郎上个月的访问，当时他会见了台湾总统蔡英文。

麻生太郎在当地的一个论坛上表示，日本需要表现出为台湾“战斗的决心”。北京表示，这一言论损害了“中日关系的政治基础”。

Kaori Kaneko、Yukiko Toyoda、Tim Kelly 和 Sakura Murakami 报道，Nobuhiro Kubo 和 Ben Blanchard 补充报道，Nick Macfie 编辑 ; Tue, 12 Sep 2023 10:43:00 GMT https://www.reuters.com/world/asia-pacific/japan-elevates-taiwan-security-ties-move-likely-rile-china-2023-09-12/ https://www.reuters.com/world/asia-pacific/japan-elevates-taiwan-security-ties-move-likely-rile-china-2023-09-12/Kaori Kaneko, Yukiko Toyoda, Tim Kelly, Sakura Murakami台湾JAPAN/DEFENCE (EXCLUSIVE, PIX) Exclusive: Ukraine's Antonov turns to drones in response to Russian invasion

Ukraine's Antonov is expanding in drone making, a presentation by the country's umbrella defence group seen by Reuters shows, as it diversifies its core cargo plane business in response to Russia's invasion.

Drones made and adapted in Ukraine play a major part in the war and Antonov's previously unreported move is consistent with Ukraine's aim to be a global drone hub, boosted by investment in a sector that has grown dramatically since early 2022.

Antonov's new drone centre was opened "with the aim of enhancing unmanned systems manufacturing capabilities and providing support to private unmanned systems manufacturers in terms of expertise and services," the presentation by Ukroboronprom, which oversees Ukraine's defence sector, said.

It was made to officials in Washington, DC, in June.

Antonov did not respond to requests for comment on the centre and expansion plans in the drone sector. A Ukroboronprom spokesperson declined to comment, citing security concerns.

Drone-making could now support legacy Soviet aerospace firms like Antonov that they have lost a major customer in Russia and suffered extensive damage from Russian attacks.

Under Ukroboronprom, Antonov has designed and built drones in the past, including the Horlytsia model, but cargo planes have long been its primary focus. In a symbolic blow, the An-225 Mriya, at the time the world's largest cargo plane and for which Antonov is best known, was destroyed early on in the war.

While cargo plane manufacturing will continue, the new drone centre could better serve Ukraine's war needs now and give Antonov's engineers more work, a person with knowledge of Antonov's plans told Reuters.

The individual could not be named because Antonov's drone plans are not yet publicly known.

Antonov's expertise in cargo planes could also be applied to long-distance drones, the source added, giving Ukraine's armed forces the capability to strike deeper into Russian territory.

Kyiv does not claim responsibility for attacking Russian soil, but experts and Western officials say it is behind intensifying drone incursions.

The new Antonov centre offers services including experimental aerodynamic studies, the creation of fully functional simulators for training Unmanned Aerial Vehicle (UAV) operators and developing component standards, according the presentation, which listed 26 functions.

LIVE TESTING

Kyiv has used aerial drones to attack airfields and Russian troops and aquatic drones against ships and a bridge. It also presents itself as a live battlefield testing ground for drone innovations by the world's defence suppliers.

Ukraine was mostly reliant on foreign UAVs after Russia began its invasion on Feb. 24, 2022, but is now able to produce a significant quantity of various types of drone following an intensive drive to support new manufacturers.

The proportion of domestic to foreign drones in Ukraine's arsenal is hard to estimate due to the high number of systems being used, their steep attrition rate, and wartime secrecy.

According to recent statements by senior officials, Ukraine has around 200 drone manufacturers and its armed forces have signed supply contracts for 30 new models of domestically produced drones.

However, most of these are start-ups founded after the invasion and operating at small scale, often lacking the production capacity and industry support needed to become significant players.

Ukrainian officials have said they want to capitalize on their Soviet-trained engineering talent to develop the post-war economy. That would include creating jobs in the drone industry.

A smaller-scale Ukrainian dronemaker visited by Reuters this year employs ex-Antonov engineers to make long-range drones.

The presentation coincides with a restructuring at Ukroboronprom aimed at attracting more customers and bolstering Ukraine's role in the international defence sector.

"The defence sector will be number one in Ukraine very soon," Ukraine's Strategic Industries Minister Oleksandr Kamyshin told Reuters, adding that drones were an essential part of aerospace industry investment.

"We have to focus on producing more weapons and ammunition locally," he added.

More broadly, Ukraine wants to invest more heavily in aircraft repair and construction, with Kamyshin saying giants like Antonov and others will probably "only grow".

However, the presentation also said Ukroboronprom intended to offload about 50% of its assets, which it described as "inefficiently utilized and unrelated to production".

"I returned from Derna. It is very disastrous. Bodies are lying everywhere - in the sea, in the valleys, under the buildings," Hichem Chkiouat, minister of civil aviation and member of the emergency committee, told Reuters by phone.

North Korean leader Kim Jong Un has arrived in Russia, Japanese media reported on Tuesday, for what the Kremlin said would be a comprehensive discussion with President Vladimir Putin amid warnings from Washington they should not agree on an arms deal.

Kim left Pyongyang for Russia on Sunday on his private train, the North's state media reported on Tuesday, accompanied by top arms industry and military officials and the foreign minister.

Japan's Kyodo news agency reported on Tuesday, citing an unnamed Russian official source, that a train carrying Kim had arrived at Khasan station, the main rail gateway to Russia's Far East from North Korea.

"It will be a full-fledged visit," Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov said. "There will be negotiations between two delegations, and after that, if necessary, the leaders will continue their communication in a one-on-one format."

An official at the Khasan administration declined to comment on the report of Kim's arrival.

Putin was expected to arrive in Vladivostok on Tuesday, where he was scheduled to attend the main session of the Eastern Economic Forum, which runs through Wednesday.

His meetings with Kim were expected to be on the sidelines of the forum, although there has been no confirmation of the location or whether Kim would attend the event.

US officials, who first said the visit was imminent, said that arms talks between Russia and North Korea were actively advancing and that Kim and Putin are likely to discuss providing Russia with weapons for the war in Ukraine.

Pyongyang and Moscow have denied that North Korea would supply arms to Russia, which has expended vast stocks of weapons in more than 18 months of war.

North Korea's KCNA state news agency said Kim was accompanied by leading officials of the ruling Workers' Party, government and armed forces.

Washington and its allies have been voicing concern at recent signs of closer military cooperation between Russia and the nuclear-armed North. It will be Kim's second summit with Putin, after they met in 2019.

DELEGATION OF DEFENCE OFFICIALS

The North Korean delegation includes prominent members of the party who handle defence industry and military affairs, including Munitions Industry Department Director Jo Chun Ryong, an analyst said, which suggests the visit will focus on defence industry cooperation.

"The presence of Jo Chun Ryong indicates that North Korea and Russia will conclude some type of agreement for munitions purchases," said Michael Madden, a North Korea leadership expert at the Washington-based Stimson Center.

Photos released by state media showed military honour guards and crowds of people in dark suits and colourful dresses waving flowers and flags as Kim boarded the dark-green train, which is believed to be armoured and carry other specialised equipment.

On Monday, as the train was bound for the Russian border, Washington renewed its warnings to Pyongyang not to sell arms to Russia that could be used in the Ukraine war.

"We urge the DPRK to abide by the public commitments that Pyongyang has made to not provide or sell arms to Russia," said Adrienne Watson, spokesperson for the White House National Security Council.

DPRK is short for the North's official name, the Democratic People's Republic of Korea.

The US State Department said any transfer of arms from North Korea to Russia would violate multiple UN Security Council resolutions, which ban any arms transactions with North Korea.

"We, of course, have aggressively enforced our sanctions against entities that fund Russia's war effort, and we will continue to enforce those sanctions and will not hesitate to impose new sanctions appropriately," State Department spokesperson Matthew Miller told reporters.

North Korea is one of the few countries to have openly supported Russia since the invasion of Ukraine last year, and Putin pledged last week to "expand bilateral ties in all respects in a planned way by pooling efforts".

In a striking display of those deepening ties, Kim gave a personal tour of an arms exhibition for Russian Defence Minister Sergei Shoigu when he visited Pyongyang in July, and they stood together to watch a military parade that featured banned ballistic missiles.

Russia had voted, along with China, to approve UN Security Council resolutions as late as 2017 punishing North Korea for launching ballistic missiles and conducting underground nuclear tests.

Peskov said the main topic of the talks by Putin and Kim would be bilateral relations between the neighbouring countries.

"We will continue to strengthen our friendship," Peskov said.

Villagers in parts of Morocco devastated by the country's biggest earthquake in over a century camped outside for a fourth night on Monday, as the death toll rose to more than 2,800 people.

Search teams from Spain, Britain and Qatar joined Moroccan efforts to find survivors from the 6.8 magnitude quake that struck in the High Atlas Mountains late on Friday, flattening the traditional mud brick houses ubiquitous in the region.

State TV reported late on Monday that the death toll had risen to 2,862, with 2,562 people injured. With much of the quake zone in hard-to-reach areas, authorities have not issued any estimates for the number of missing.

In the village of Tinmel, almost every house was pulverised and the entire community has been left homeless. The stench of death from dozens of animals buried under the rubble wafts through parts of the village.

Mouhamad Elhasan, 59, said he had been eating dinner with his family when the earthquake struck. His 31-year-old son fled outside and was hit as their neighbour's roof collapsed, trapping him under the rubble.

Elhasan said he searched for his son as he cried for help. But eventually the cries stopped, and by the time he reached his son he was dead. Elhasan and his wife and daughter remained inside their home and survived.

"If he had stayed inside the house he would have been ok," Elhasan said.

In Tinmel and in other villages residents said they had pulled people out of the rubble with their bare hands.

In Tikekhte, where few buildings have been left standing, 66-year-old Mohamed Ouchen described how residents rescued 25 people - one of whom was his sister.

"We were busy rescuing. Because we didn't have tools, we used our hands," he said. "Her head was visible and we kept digging by hand."

Footage from the remote village of Imi N'Tala, filmed by Spanish rescuer Antonio Nogales of the aid group Bomberos Unidos Sin Fronteras (United Firefighters Without Borders), showed men and dogs clambering over steep slopes covered in rubble.

"The level of destruction is ... absolute," said Nogales on Monday, struggling to find the right word to describe what he was seeing. "Not a single house has stayed upright."

Despite the scale of the damage, he said rescuers searching with dogs still hoped to find survivors.

The epicentre of the quake was about 72 km (45 miles) southwest of Marrakech, where some historical buildings in the old city, a UNESCO World Heritage Site, were damaged. The quake also did major damage to the historically significant 12th-century Tinmel Mosque .

More modern parts of Marrakech largely escaped unscathed, including a site near the airport earmarked for IMF and World Bank meetings , due to be held next month.

Over 10,000 people are expected at the meetings, which the Moroccan government wants to proceed, sources said.

RESCUE CONTINUES

After an initial response that was described as too slow by some survivors, tent camps appeared in some locations by Monday night as people spent a fourth night outdoors.

The army said it was reinforcing search-and-rescue teams, providing drinking water, and distributing food, tents and blankets.

A major road connecting the High Atlas Mountains to Marrakech was gridlocked on Monday evening as heavy vehicles and volunteers carrying relief supplies headed towards some of the hardest-hit communities.

Moroccan volunteers and civilians, aided by some foreigners, helped direct traffic and clear the road of rock debris.

Morocco has accepted offers of aid from Spain and Britain, which both sent search-and-rescue specialists with sniffer dogs, and from the United Arab Emirates and Qatar. Algeria said it had allocated three planes to transport rescue personnel and aid. State TV said the Moroccan government might accept relief offers from other countries later.
